She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. 

Her hope is to be financially stable and expand her agricultural sector.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and maize seeds for planting in her farm

loans.name: Shohista

texts.en:
Shohista is a hardworking woman and was born in the southern part of Tajikistan in 1992. She is living in a small town with her family. She is single and lives with her parents. She has five year experience doing business and helping her parents to earn to family budget. She rents a small store and sells grocery products. She is communicable, honest and hospitable person. She gently serves her customers and knows her duty very well. She has regular clients. 

She wishes to enlarge her business and decided to appeal to IMON asking a loan to add additional goods such as vegetables and fruits for her store. She is hoping to be supported by Kiva lenders and awaits your compassion. 

She wants to be helpful and support her parents to live.

loans.use: to buy additional goods such as vegetables and fruits for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to use in opening a new butchery

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Hariyanto

texts.en:
Good day, lenders!  This is Hariyanto, one of Ruma’s agents. 

Hariyanto lives in Bekasi, a suburban area located about two hours drive from Jakarta. He is happily married. Together with his wife, they have one cute daughter.

He owns a stall that sells small snacks, drinks and mobile airtime credits to his community. He joined Ruma almost a year ago. He knew Ruma from a Ruma sales executive who came to his stall. He decided to join Ruma because he wants to expand his business in technology. 

As the business grows, Hariyanto is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits to his community.  Your loan will be very useful to help Hariyanto improve his business and, accordingly, his community, which needs access to such services. 

Hariyanto's goal in the near future is to serve an e-commerce business for low communities, so his community can have access to better products with lower prices. He thanks you for your kind support.

loans.use: to purchase prepaid airtime credits to help community members who need access to communication service.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 42 years old and married to David.  She supports three children. 

She has been a dairy farmer for the past 13 years, and her business earns her KES 11,000 per month. 

She has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to buy a dairy cow for milk production so as to increase her milk supply clients and meet their demands for milk.

She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. 

Her hope is to be financially stable and expand her agricultural sector.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production

loans.name: Manessa 1 Group

texts.en:
Suzan is the featured borrower for Manessa 1 Group. She joined with her other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. They are working hard to develop their businesses and living at the same time.

Suzan is a 24-year-old married woman who opened four years ago her beauty salon to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family. She is well-known in her area for her professional skills. 

Today, she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy the necessary beauty tools and summer cosmetics to satisfy her customers' special requests. Suzan is the first lady on the left of the photo.  Nahiya is the lady sitting in the middle, and Khetam is the first lady on the right of the photo.

loans.use: to buy the necessary beauty tools for her salon and summer cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy another motorcycle to transport more people to new destinations

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: buy all the needs for her stall as mosquito repellent, noodles, eggs, vegetables, petroleum, wood cutting machine, chisel, etc

loans.name: Philemon

texts.en:
Philemon is a new member of Juhudi Kilimo, which is a micro-finance targeting smallholder farmers who are in dire need of capital but lack access to financial services. He is determined to diversify his dairy business to include other activities such as crop farming. 

His biggest challenge is that he lives in a part of Kenya where there are no banks and therefore he has no access to capital to buy agricultural inputs - improved seeds and fertilizer. 

Luckily for him, he got linked to Juhudi Kilimo, through which he is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to buy improved seeds and fertilizer ahead of planting season. 

With your lending, Philemon will be able to access capital from a licensed and credible source to buy important farm inputs that will increase his farm’s productivity and elevate his family’s livelihood.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy additional fish for her store, seeds, fertilizer and kitchen equipment for a business

loans.name: Samsudin

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Samsudin, one of Ruma's agents. Samsudin lives in North Bogor, located about one hour and thirty minutes drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. Samsudin lives there with his wife and his only son. Samsudin owns a stall where he sells mobile airtime credits for his community. He joined Ruma since 2014. He also feels happy joined Ruma because for him,  Ruma’s services is the best. He learnt a lot about how to manage his business from Ruma, as well as manage his income and saving.

As the business grows, Samsudin is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile payment services to his community, especially on weekends. Having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help Samsudin improves his business and accordingly, his community who needs access to such services. Samsudin is the one who is seen in the photo. He will be thankful for your kind and endless support.

loans.use: to process more prepaid mobile airtime purchases and electricity bill payments for members of his local community.

loans.name: Rael

texts.en:
Rael is a 47 years old. She is married and blessed with 3 children.

She is a fresh water vendor based in in Mombasa Kenya, a business she has done and it has been profitable. 

This marks her forth borrowing from VisionFund Kenya and  will use the loan to purchase a second water tank for storing fresh water to sell to the community around.

With the anticipated profits, Rael will be able to service her loan. 

She hopes to flourish more in her business in the near future as she serves more members of her community.

loans.use: to purchase a second water tank for storing fresh water to sell to the community around

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter lives together with his wife and 4 children in Kitale, Kenya. Dairy, poultry and horticultural farming provides them with a livelihood and decent income. Peter has been farming for 19 years and this year he want to grow the business further. 

A big problem smallholder farmers, like Peter, face when trying to increase productivity is where to get the capital to buy modern agricultural inputs and farm implements. Peter lives in a part of Kenya where there are no banks. Peter is now linked with Juhudi Kilimo, which is a microfinance whose aim is to serve smallholder farmers with no access to financial services that they need. 

Peter is seeking a loan to buy farm implements. Acquisition of these tools will enable him to cultivate more land and produce more food for his family and for sale. Income generated from selling crop produce will help him meet his family's basic needs.

loans.use: to buy farm implements

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 52 years, married to Zipporah old and he supports 5 children. 

He has been a dairy farmer for the last 18 year and the business earns him KES 10,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase a dairy cow so as to increase the number of litres of milk supplied to clients daily.  

He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate his children. 

His hope is to be financially stable and expand his agricultural sector.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow so as to increase the number of litres of milk supplied to clients daily.

loans.name: Ardiyah

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! This is Ardiyah, one of Ruma's agents. Ardiyah lives in Depok, a suburb located 1 hour and 30 minutes drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. She lives there with her husband and her two children. Ardiyah owns a stall that sells women's outfits and mobile airtime credits. As a woman, she realized that she has to help her husband increase their income, which is why she decided to join Ruma last year. She feels happy as well because she can contribute more to her community. Ardiyah is a hardworking woman and her community sees her as a cheerful and kind mobile service provider.

As the business grows, Ardiyah needs additional capital and is seeking a working capital loan from Kiva. She will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits for her community. Ardiyah’s goal with Ruma in the near future is to provide an e-commerce business for her community, with Ruma’s latest product called Mapan, so later on her community can have access to better products with lower prices. Ardiyah is the one who is seen in the photo. She is thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to give her community better access to communication service by selling mobile airtime credits.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 47 years old, married to Omboga and she supports 5 children. 

She has been a farmer for the last 13 years and the business earns her KES 10,000 per month. 

She has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase fertilizers and maize seeds for planting in her farm so as to produce enough for family use and others for sale to clients in the market.

She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her children. 

Her hope is to be financially stable and expand her agricultural sector.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and maize seeds for planting in her farm so as to produce enough for family use and others for sale to clients in the market.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs for use in the farm for high production and supply for more income gain.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is a Kiva borrower. She operates a retail business where she sells bread, flour, cooking fat, sweets, soap, sugar and other items. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be low capital. She will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread,flour,soap and other items.This will enable her increase sales hence more profit. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years. She will use the anticipated profits to improve her life.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour,soap and other items

loans.name: Tintin

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! Now it’s time for you to meet one of Ruma’s agents, Tintin. Tintin lives in South Tangerang, located about an hour drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. She owns a stall where she sells daily consumer products, mobile airtime credits and provide electricity payment service for her community. She joined Ruma last year. As a woman, she wanted to join Ruma because she wants to learn about how to improve her business in technology, as well as give more contribution to her community. 

As the business grows, Tintin is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. She will use the capital to provide more mobile payment services to her community, especially on weekends. Having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help Tintin improves her business and accordingly, her community who needs access to such services. As seen in the photo, Tintin is the one who is holding Ruma's banner. She will be thankful for your support.

loans.use: to process more prepaid mobile airtime purchases and electricity bill payments for members of her local community.

loans.name: Nolusindiso

texts.en:
Nolusindiso is a Business Management Student at the Maharishi Institute and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute: This is her story:
1.	What do you study at the Maharishi Institute? Which classes do you enjoy the most? I am studying a bachelor of Arts in Business Administration. The class that I enjoy most is Principles of Economics and Organizing and Management.

2.	What are your goals after graduating from the Maharishi Institute? Please be specific: in which sector do you expect to work? In which city would you like to work? Would you like to travel? My goals after graduating from the Maharishi Institute is to work for a company that will groom me into a corporate professional. I would like to start my own business.
3.	Tell us about your background. Where were you born? Do you have brothers and sisters? What do your parents do for work? Are you married; do you have children? I am Nolusindiso, I was born in Eastern Cape in a town called Queenstown. I am the second last born child. I have one brother and eight sisters. My mother is a single parent. My father passed on when I was twelve years old. My mother does not work and lives off her social grant. I am not married  and I am not planning to get married anytime soon.  I do not have children and I am not planning to have anytime soon. My plan is to finish school and start my own business.

4.	What do you like to do in your spare time? During my spare time I do art. I enjoy visiting art galleries and would love to display my work one day. I also like to design clothes for myself and design things for my home.
5.	How will Kiva loan change your life? Describe how the loan will affect your studies and your lifestyle: will there be significant changes? The Kiva loan will change my life, as I will be able to pay my rent early without stressing about where I am I going to get the money. I will be able to buy groceries like other students and also I will be able to do my complete my studies every day.

loans.use: to pay for one year tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Isabellah

texts.en:
Isabella is 35 years old, married to Kenneth and she supports 2 children. 
She has been a farmer for the last 4 years and the business earns her KES 11,000 per month. She has applied for her first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase fertilizers for topdressing her crops so as to increase the productivity for family use and others for sale in the market.

She plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate her child. 
Her hope is to be financially stable and expand her agricultural sector.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for topdressing her crops so as to increase the productivity for family use and educate her child.

loans.name: King Of Kings J. School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Andrew. He is the Head teacher of King of Kings Junior School, a mixed school in the Rural area of Igamba in Iganga. King of Kings J. School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

King of Kings J. School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Andrew ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his students’ concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: To purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Biakoye Group

texts.en:
This group is begin its sixth cycle with ID-Ghana in the Teshie branch. It is comprised of two members and led by Faustina. The businesses that the members carry out are varied and include making and selling fante kenkey (cooked corn paste) and grocery. The loan that they will take out will benefit small businesswomen where Faustina is a member. She says that she has been a member of ID-Ghana, Teshie branch for four years. She joined by invitation from a friend who is a member of the institution. She currently has a business of selling fante kenkey (cooked corn paste). She says that she learned this business on her own initiative with the first loan that she got from the institution four years ago.

The loan that she will now take out is to increase capital  that she will get from the wholesaler in the city of Accra. She is married and has three children.

When asked what she likes about ID-Ghana, she replied that she likes the health services and the training that the institution provides.

loans.use: to buy corn paste, firewood to prepare kenkey and sell to customers

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.en:
Shahnoza is a cheerful woman. She was born in the southern part of Tajikistan in 1985 and is living in a remote district with her family. The standard of their living is not good. She is married and has three children. More than five years she has been a teacher and teaches students at a secondary school. 

The salary that she earns from her job is not enough to pay her children tuition fees for studies, so she appealed to IMON asking for a loan to pay her children’s tuition fees. She hopes to be supported and awaits Kiva lenders kindness.

loans.use: to pay her children’s tuition fees

loans.name: Carlos Mauricio

texts.es:
Carlos de 32 años de edad, casado con un hijo de siete meses de edad, es originario de  Managua, y se caracteriza por ser trabajador, honrado, trabajador, padre de familia, responsables en los crédito anteriores ha pagado en tiempo y forma, lamentablemente por fatal de recursos no siguió estudiando, en la actualidad lucha para sacar adelante a su familia, 
Gracias a sus ganas de salir adelante tiene por actividad económica el servicio de taxi, negocio que lo desempeña de forma ambulante y  servicio privados, tiene cinco años de desempeñarse en dicha actividad, con gran esfuerzo pudo adquirir su unidad de taxi el cual ya pudo terminar de pagar. Su rutina de trabajo es de unas doce horas diarias brindando su servicio. Desde las 6: am a las 6: pm que se lo entrega a un cadete que lo trabaje por la noche. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en  el mantenimiento de la unidad de su taxi, y comprarle llantas nuevas, para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes y aumentar sus ganancias en un futuro no muy lejano. Carlos agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un  medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Carlos, 32 years old, married with a seven month old son, is a native of Managua, and is characterized as a hardworking, honest, and hardworking family man that has been responsible in previous loans, which he has paid in a timely manner. Unfortunately, because of lack of resources, he did not continue studying. Now he is struggling to provide for his family.

Thanks to his desire to succeed, he has taken up a taxi service, a business that provides both public and private service. He has five years of experience in this business, and with great effort he was able to purchase a taxi cab which he has already finished paying. His provides his service for about twelve hours a day. He works from 6 am to 6 pm, when he delivers the taxi to a cadet who works at night.

The purpose of the loan is to invest in the maintenance of his taxi and to buy new tires in order to better serve his customers and increase profits in the not too distant future. Carlos thanks the assistance that Kiva investors have given to those lacking resources and to poor countries such as Nicaragua, which helps them have a dignified job.

loans.use: to invest into his taxi and to buy new tires.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene lives in Kampala, Uganda and is married with 2 children and all go to school. She takes care of one additional family member. She operates a boutique selling used clothes. She has been in this business for the last 4 years, where she works seven days a week. 

She has requested for a loan of 500,000 from MCDT – SACCO to buy a bale of used clothes. Her major challenge includes seasonality and transportation. Her goal and aspiration is to build permanent business premises. She lives in rented house and the family has access to piped water and electricity. Her major monthly expenses include school fees,rent and food.

loans.use: To buy a bale of used clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more stocks of tomatoes for sale to clients to meet both client and family needs.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a married woman and has 6 children. She describes herself to be trustworthy. She operates a retail business where she sells baobab tree seeds. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located in a rural area and her primary customers are hotels. 

She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy more stock of baobab seeds. Her business goal is to be a wholesaler within 5 years. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of baobab tree seeds

loans.name: Miguel Enrique

texts.es: Miguel de 37 años, inició su propio negocio de tienda de víveres en el municipio de San Jacinto en el Departamento de Bolívar, aprovechado la experiencia obtenida al haber laborado durante años en el vecino país de Venezuela en negocios de este mismo formato, llego con mucha expectativa de progresar a este municipio.  Todos los días al amanecer los residentes del sector pueden realizar sus compras de los víveres que hacen parte de la canasta familiar; leche, queso, huevo, carne, frutas y verduras, detergentes  y demás. Miguel es muy comprometido con su negocio puesto que es el sustento para su familia, él es padre de seis hijos menores de edad a quienes les brinda bienestar fruto de su trabajo.  Para mantener bien surtida su tienda es necesario realizar unas compras, para ello está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, que invertirá en canastas de cervezas, gaseosas y víveres de alta rotación como arroz, aceite, legumbres y demás.  Su meta a largo plazo es ubicar su negocio en un sector de mayores ventas.
texts.en:
Miguel is 37 years old. He started his own business, a grocery store, in the town of San Jacinto in the department of Bolivar. He used the experience he obtained working for years in the neighboring country of Venezuela in a business with the same format. He came in with great expectations of progress in this city. Every day at dawn neighborhood residents can shop for groceries that are part of the basic family needs: milk, cheese, eggs, meat, fruit, and vegetables, detergent, and more. 

Miguel is very committed to his business since it provides the sustenance for his family. He is a father of six children who are the fruit of his labor. To keep the store well stocked it is necessary for him to do some shopping. For this reason he is applying for a loan through Kiva. This is his first loan through the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that he will invest in staples such as beer, soft drinks and high turnover food such as rice, oil, beans, and more. His goal is to locate his business in a sector of higher sales.

loans.use: to invest in staple items: beers, soft drinks, and high turnover food such as rice, oil, beans, and others.

loans.name: Kelebogile

texts.en:
Kelebogile is a Business Management Student at the Maharishi Institute and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute: This is her story:1.	What do you study at the Maharishi Institute? Which classes do you enjoy the most?
I am currently doing a Bachelor of Arts in Business Administration and this is my 4th year. The class I enjoy the most is Marketing class because in Marketing I liked the way you get to broaden your mind and be creative.

2.	What are your goals after graduating from the Maharishi Institute? Please be specific: in which sector do you expect to work? In which city would you like to work? Would you like to travel? My goal after graduating from the Maharishi Institute is to work in the corporate world in one of the biggest companies in South Africa. I know that I can do this because the Maharishi Institute aims to produce the best students ever and we get qualifications that not everyone can get. They don’t want to us to just earn the qualification, they are building and creating the best out of us and that way I want to be in the best company, where I will be able to learn and get the best experience.

3.	Tell us about your background. Where were you born? Do you have brothers and sisters? What do your parents do for work? Are you married; do you have children? 
I was born in a family of five; 3 sisters and 1 brother. I live with my mother and she is unemployed. I don’t have a child and I am not married.

4.	What do you like to do in your spare time? 
In my spare time I do some volunteering work in my community where we teach children how to play different instruments and help them with their school work
.
5.	How will Kiva loan change your life? Describe how the loan will affect your studies and your lifestyle: will there be significant changes?
The Kiva loan will change my life in a good way because I come from a family were no one is working. With the Kiva loan I will be able to use that money for transport to come to school so that I won’t be absent most of the time as I am often at the moment.

loans.use: to pay for one year tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Iganga Boys School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Michael. He is the Head teacher of Iganga Boys Primary School, a mixed school in the Urban area of Iganga with 600 students. Iganga Boys School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 750 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

Iganga Boy's School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Michael ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his students’ concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: To purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Gulhinamo

texts.ru: Гулхинамо  38 лет. Она мама и мать детей. Муж Гулхинамо в течение 20 лет занимается мастером по ремонту домов.  Она с семьей живет в городке Куляб. Гулхинамо домохозяйка в основном свое сводное время проводит дома, но решила не сидеть без дел, и заниматься шитьем женской одежды. У нее хорошо, получается, шить женские одежды. Она 5 лет продвигает свою работу. Гулхинамо сидя дома зарабатывает на жизнь. Она хочет взять кредит для купли швейные принадлежности для расширения маленького бизнеса. Гулхинамо заранее выражает свою благодарность.
texts.en: Gulhinamo is 38 years old, and she is a mother. Her husband has been an expert house repairer for 20 years. Gulhinamo lives with her family in Kulob. She is a housewife and she runs the house in her own free time, but she decided to work, as well, by sewing women's clothing. It turns out that she is good at sewing women's clothing, and she has been doing this work for 5 years. Gulhinamo earns her living from home. She wants to get a loan to buy sewing supplies to expand her small business. Gulhinamo expresses her thanks in advance.

loans.use: to buy sewing supplies to expand her business.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel is 41 years old, married to Josephine and he supports 7 family members. 

He has been a farmer for the last 19 year and the business earns him KES 10,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers so as for top dressing his crops in the farm for a better harvest for family use and sale in the market.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate himself. 

His hope is to be financially stable and expand his agricultural sector.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers so as for top dressing his crops in the farm for a better harvest for family use and to educate himself

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is a married woman with 4 children. She describes herself to be trustworthy. She operates a retail business where she sells onions, cabbages, tomatoes, avocado. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in a competitive area and her primary customers are locals. 

She will use the Kes 100,000 loan to buy more stock of cabbages, tomatoes, onions, avocado. This will enable her to increase sales and also profit.Her business goal is to be a big supplier of vegetables within 5 years. This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to add more stock.

loans.use: buy more stock of cabbages, tomatoes, onions, avocado

loans.name: Dalia Modesta

texts.es: Dalia de 58 años, confecciona uniformes empresariales y todo tipo de ropa para damas y caballeros. Nació en una familia muy numerosa, eran diez mujeres de las cuales solo ella no estudio una carrera profesional, consideró que su vocación desde niña fueron las confecciones y que se dedicaría a este arte.  Hoy en día cuenta con 25 años de experiencia y una clientela fidelizada a quienes elabora modernas prendas de vestir a su medida y con diseños a la vanguardia. Su propósito a largo plazo es mejorar las condiciones de la casa en la que vive, es por esa razón que Dalia labora en su taller por varias horas y para lograr cumplir con los pedidos de sus clientes está aplicando a su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo el cual invertirá en tela oxford,  tela lacoite, tela anti fluido, lino strech y demás. Ella va a producir a todo costo y con ésta propuesta en su negocio aumentará la productividad y dará una acabado de calidad al producto final.
texts.en:
Dalia, 58 years old, makes corporate uniforms and other types of clothes for women and men. She was born into a very large family. They were ten women, of which she is the only one not to have studied a professional career. Since she was a girl, she considered her vocation to be tailoring, and she decided to dedicate herself to this art. Today, she has 25 years of experience and a loyal customer base, for whom she makes modern clothes tailored to fit with cutting-edge designs.

Her goal for the long run is to improve the conditions of the house in which she lives. For this reason, Dalia works long hours in her workshop, and in order to meet her customers' demands, she is applying for her first loan with the Foundation Mario Santo Domingo. She will invest in oxford cloth, lacoite cloth, fluid-resistant fabric, stretch linen and more. She wants to keep producing at all costs and with this loan, the productivity of her business will improve and her final product will be of higher quality.

loans.use: to invest in oxford cloth, lacoite cloth, fluid-resistant fabric, stretch linen and more.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is 41 years old active borrower of BRAC Pakistan, residing in Rawalpindi, Pakistan with her spouse and six children. Her husband has been running own tailoring shop in the local market for 5 years and he is responsible to fulfill the needs of entire family.

Fatima's husband needs to buy different types of tailoring accessories e.g. pieces of cloth, laces needles and sewing machine accessories. But due to some financial constraints her husband is not in suitable condition to buy above these items for his business purpose. Therefore Fatima has applied for Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. With the help of this loan amount she will financially assist her husband to above these tailoring accessories to fulfill his business needs, so that her husband can earn more profitable income.

For this financial assistance Fatima is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her husband's tailoring business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs for use in the farm for high production and supply for more income gain.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a 27-year-old married mother of two children, who started a year ago working as a hairdresser from her house to help her husband in covering the increasing needs and expenses of their children. She is an ambitious lady who has a good reputation among her region and has her loyal customers.
Zainab is working hard to develop her business and improve her family's living conditions. 

Today, she is acquiring a YOUTH loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy updated beauty tools and summer cosmetics, as she wants to pay her children school tuition fees. 
Zainab hopes to expand her business more in the future to increase her income and stay capable of improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy updated beauty tools and summer cosmetics so as to pay her children school tuition fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to supply milk to the market for more income gain.

loans.name: Shamshad

texts.en:
Shamshad is responsible mother of seven children and lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been providing transport facilities by driving a taxi for 22 years. Her husband is responsible to fulfill the needs of entire family. Her husband needs to do maintenance on his taxi because the current condition of his taxi is not good as it requires more maintenance charges on a daily basis. 

Due to insufficient financial means her husband is unable to make maintenance of his taxi. Therefore Shamshad has applied for Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

With the help of this loan Shamshad's husband can afford the maintenance cost easily. And provide the better transport facilities to earn the profitable income. Shamshad  also plans to make savings with the profit amount of her husband's income to meet her family's needs in future.
Shamshad is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to repair her husband's taxi

loans.name: Zachary

texts.en:
Zachary is 36 years old and he supports 5 family members. 

He has been a farmer for the last 12 year and the business earns him KES 9,000 per month. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from VisionFund Kenya to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers so as for top dressing his crops in the farm for a better harvest for family use and sale in the market.

He plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and educate himself. 

His hope is to be financially stable and expand his agricultural sector.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers so as for top dressing his crops in the farm for a better harvest for family use and sale in the market

loans.name: Bibihol

texts.en:
Bibihol is a hardworking woman. She was born in the southern part of Tajikistan in 1973. She is living in a big remote town with her family. She is a widow and has four children. She works at a government agency. 

It is hard for her to feed and ensure her children's care alone. She does not have money to pay her son’s tuition fee. She appealed to IMON, asking for a loan to pay for her son’s higher education costs. She hopes her children will be educated and have professional work. She awaits Kiva lenders' compassion.

loans.use: to pay for her son’s higher education costs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm inputs and thus improve his family's livelihood

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farm inputs for use in the farm for high production and supply for more income gain and also educate his children

loans.name: Phumla

texts.en:
Phumla is a Business Management Student at the Maharishi Institute and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute: This is her story:1.	What do you study at the Maharishi Institute? Which classes do you enjoy the most? I am studying a Bachelor of Arts in business administration. I am doing my fourth year. The class that I enjoy the most is Algebra because it is the most challenging and interesting at the same time.

2.	What are your goals after graduating from the Maharishi Institute? Please be specific: in which sector do you expect to work? In which city would you like to work? Would you like to travel? After graduating I hope to work in the finance department, which is the field that I am interested in. I also want to open my own business so that I can support my family and improve other people’s lives. 

3.	Tell us about your background. Where were you born? Do you have brothers and sisters? What do your parents do for work? Are you married; do you have children? I am Phumla originally from the Eastern Cape, currently staying Carletonville in Johannesburg. I am 31 years old and the mother of two children. I am the third born from a family of eight. I am the bread winner at home, even though I study full time. I had to find better work in order to support my family, which is why I decided to further my education because I know that education will open doors for me.

4.	What do you like to do in your spare time? During my leisure time I go to people’s homes where I volunteer my time into help them in whatever way they need assistance. I also read books and watch television.
5.	How will Kiva loan change your life? Describe how the loan will affect your studies and your lifestyle: will there be significant changes? A Kiva loan will change my life in  a positive way because I will be able to come to school without worrying and stressing about school fees. It will help  in terms of transport money too. I will be able to come early, as I have been struggling to come to school on time. This loan will have a huge impact in my lifestyle as I will be able to be a better student in terms of academics.

loans.use: to pay for one year tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a married man. He has five children. He operates a retail business where he sells timber. He has been involved in this business for 11 years. His business is located in an area with potential, and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

He will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more trees to make timber. He hopes that in the future, he will create employment. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more trees to make timber

loans.name: Bishop Willis School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Stephen. He is the Principal of Bishop Willis Core PTC School, a mixed school in the Urban area of Iganga with 300 students. Bishop Willis School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 450 litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day. 

Bishop Willis School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Stephen ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his students’ concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: To purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Fouzia

texts.en:
Fouzia is a responsible mother of one son. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been providing transport facilities by driving a taxi for six years. Her husband is responsible for fulfilling the needs of the entire family. 

Her husband needs to make maintenance on his taxi because the current condition of his taxi is not good; it requires more maintenance charges on a daily basis. Due to insufficient financial means, her husband is unable to make maintenance on his taxi. Therefore, Fouzia has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

With the help of this loan, Fouzia's husband can afford the maintenance cost easily and provide better transport facilities to earn profitable income. 

Fouzia also plans to make savings with the profit amount of her husband's income to meet her family's needs in the future.

Fouzia is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to repair her husband's taxi

loans.name: Bridgeview Group

texts.en:
Early morning before the break of dawn, a woman named Jane wakes up to cut cloth. She then goes to her sewing machine and starts sewing school uniforms. Due to the constant blackouts caused by the electricity load shedding, Jane has to sew the uniforms using her manual sewing machine in candle light. Although her eyes have been affected by years of straining from sewing in a dimly lit room, Jane remains strong and continues working for her family.

Just as the first rays of the sun start emerging in the blue June sky, she leaves her work and prepares breakfast for her four children. When her children leave home for school, Jane goes to the market, were she does most of her work. At the market place, where many other tailors operate, Jane finds some of her customers already waiting for the uniforms and others for placing orders for more uniforms. Most of her customers sell these uniforms in the rural areas at more affordable as prices compared to those charged in shops. 

Jane has been in this business for more than 10 years now. She has two girls under her employ, helping her with sewing and selling the uniforms. She markets her business through word of mouth and going from school to school advertising the uniforms she sews. Jane has received many tenders from schools and colleges that are interested in her work. Her challenge is the lack of funding to buy the adequate material to sew these uniforms. Along with her friends who are also tailors, they formed a group called Bridgeview. They hope that a loan from Kiva will help them buy enough material enough to supply their demanding market.

loans.use: To buy enough material to supply her market.

loans.name: Shaheen

texts.en:
Shaheen is a 47-year-old, active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. She is residing in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, with her spouse and three children. Her husband has been running his own tailoring shop in the local market for nine years. Her husband is solely responsible to fulfill the needs of the entire family.

Shaheen's husband needs to buy different types of tailoring accessories, e.g., pieces of cloth, laces, needles and sewing machine accessories. But due to some financial constraints, her husband is not in suitable condition to buy these items for his business purposes. Therefore, Shaheen has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. With the help of this loan amount, she will financially assist her husband to buy these tailoring accessories to fulfill his business needs, so that her husband can earn more profitable income.

For this financial assistance, Shaheen is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her husband's tailoring business

loans.name: Manizha

texts.en:
Manizha is a hardworking girl. She was born in the northern part of Tajikistan in 1997. She is living in a small town of beautiful nature scenes each season and hospitable residents. She is single and lives with her parents. 

After graduation of high school, she helped her aunt with drying fruits. Each time she wished to have her own business. She appealed to IMON and participated in a three-day training for startup clients. She got necessary knowledge and aimed to open her own business. 

Manizha is a responsible, honest and generous person. She asks for a loan from Kiva lenders to buy fruits and dry them for further selling. She hopes to be supported, because it is her first business and she worries about it.

loans.use: to buy fruits and dry them for further selling

loans.name: Parvina

texts.en:
Parvina is a kind girl. She was born in the northern part of Tajikistan in 1993 and is living in remote district with her family. She is single and lives with her parents. She participated at a three day training provided by IMON to startup clients. 

During participation at training she made a business plan to how to keep livestock and feed them. She has a practice in this sphere and knows well market price for livestock. Her father taught her necessary and key aspects of keeping livestock. She likes her activity, because in her area this business is more profitable. 

She appealed to IMON and asked a loan to start her business. She wants to buy livestock to grow and further selling, to be productive in the future. She awaits Kiva lenders compassion.

loans.use: to buy livestock to grow and further selling to be a productive business for the future

loans.name: Shelly

texts.en:
Shelly is a 33-year-old entrepreneur living in Lusaka, the capital city of Zambia. Over the past few years, Shelly has been able to grow her business thanks to Kiva. Shelly's business helps people to send and receive money throughout the country without having to go to the bank. Shelly has accessed three loans and has fully repaid two. She is repaying her third loan very well.

Shelly has requested for a subsequent loan from Kiva to enable her to open another outlet. The funds will be used to buy a trading kiosk and provide the funds needed for her to serve new customers. This will help help to expand her business, as she anticipates that the new outlet is going to be very profitable. Once she gets this loan, Shelly will be able to employ her cousin to help her run the outlet. Shelly says through her business, she has been able to help her extended family members by offering them employment. This has helped to reduce poverty and unemployment within her circles.

Shelly continues to support her mother and pay for her sister's school fees. She thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business by opening another outlet

loans.name: Gulnaz

texts.en: Gulnaz is a 35-year-old woman. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a responsible mother of three children. Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. For the past many days, his rickshaw has not been working properly. Because of this, her husband is unable to generate any amount of income. Her husband wants to repair it as soon as possible. However due to the lack of money, he finds it difficult to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. Therefore, Gulnaz has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. This will help him to continue his business. Gulnaz is so much thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to repair her husband's rickshaw

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
Gilbert is 23 years old. He and his wife are expecting their first child. Gilbert started running his business in October 2015 whilst working as an excavator operator. When he first started, he only served 10 to 20 customers in a day, but this is no longer the case. His customers now range from at least 40 to 80 in a day. 

Gilbert believes he is going to be successful in his business because of his commitment to offer the very best customer service. He is happy to be able to provide a service that makes people’s lives easier. Running a business comes with many challenges. Gilbert’s biggest challenge is that his capital is very small and the trading booth he is currently using to conduct his business is not his. 

Gilbert needs the Kiva loan to be able to buy his own trading booth, which will have a shade, and to be able to serve customers once his capital has increased. He is hopeful that the increase in capital and the new trading booth will help him to earn more profits. The increase in profits will help Gilbert to provide for his wife and their baby that is on the way. His appeal to the kiva lenders is that they keep helping small businesses such as his because it goes a long way. 

Gilbert dreams of opening up more shops as the demand for his services keeps increasing. He anticipates that this loan will help.

loans.use: To purchase a small trading booth where he can serve people who need to access financial services in his community

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is 37 years old. He is married and has two children. Both his children go to school. Jonathan runs a local mobile money transfer business, as an agent for Zoona. He describes his business as simply the sending and receiving of money electronically, with the use of a mobile phone. 

Currently, Jonathan does not have enough working capital. He is not able to serve customers who want to send large amounts of money. This saddens him, as he has to turn away customers and lose out on valuable commissions. He is therefore requesting a Kiva loan so that he can grow his capital base and serve customers who want to transact larger sums of money.

 Jonathan believes that his community benefits from his business because he offers them an easy and quick way of sending money and he works hard to give them excellent customer service. He is constantly growing the number of transactions he does in a day.

 Jonathan is grateful for the opportunity he has to run and grow his own business. He is hopeful that through this Kiva loan, he will be able to increase the number of customers he is able to serve and earn more profits. The profits will go towards providing basic needs for his young family. He thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To serve people who need to access financial services in his community

loans.name: Tamar

texts.en: Tamar is 25 years old. She is married and lives with her husband in Telavi, East Georgia. Her husband works at local security company and gets a monthly income. Tamar is unemployed and stays home. The family owns a small vineyard. In addition, they have a plot of agricultural land where they grow maize. They sell the harvested grapes and maize locally. Tamar wants to purchase a cow and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables Tamar to get a loan. With the received money, she will purchase a cow and will start producing dairy products to sell as well as for family use.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Kwata Vata Ngutethye Women's Group

texts.en:
The women of the Kwata Vata Ngutethye Group hail from Masavoni, Kenya.  Among these women is Mueni (bottom right), a working mother of three who divides her time between caring for her family and tending to her farm.  Mueni and the other women in her group are seeking a loan so that they are able to purchase efficient charcoal cookstoves from The Paradigm Project.

These women currently cook for their families using a combination of traditional charcoal cookstoves and three-stone fires, both of which consume a large volume of fuel and produce a great deal of smoke and toxic emissions.  The stoves that these women hope to purchase from The Paradigm Project use 40% less fuel and produce roughly 64% less smoke.

Mueni intends to use the fuel savings that her new stove generates to pay her children’s school fees and to buy livestock for her farm.

loans.use: To purchase an efficient charcoal cookstove that will reduce household expenditures and make cooking faster and easier.

loans.name: Excellent Sisters Group

texts.en:
As the Harare sun rises and shines, a market just outside the tobacco auction awakens from its peaceful slumber. Vendors selling all kinds of stuff from food, clothing and even furniture stand beside their stalls and call out prices like auctioneers, and instead of a hammer, they use carrot leaves to ward off flies following the scent of fruit and vegetables on display. 

One of the voices that calls out is the voice of Miriam. She cooks sadza and potato chips and sells to the farmers, buyers and auctioneers. Miriam spends all day selling and delivering food to her customers. Her tasty food has made her well known by the vendors and the people around. She faces the hot Zimbabwean sun, cooking food using fire. Just nearby, she has a small stall selling second-hand clothes that she buys from Mozambique. 

Being a single mother, she has to work hard to send her four children to school and feed them. She wants to grow her business and make some physical improvements to her stall to protect her from the sun. 

Miriam is part of a group called Excellent Sisters. The group is taking a second loan from Thrive Microfinance. They have a good payment history, and they want to take their businesses to a higher level. They hope that a $1,450 loan from Kiva will help them achieve their ambitions.

loans.use: to expand the range of food and drink she sells from her stall.

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida is a responsible mother of six children. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been providing transportation services by driving a taxi for 12 years. Her husband is responsible for fulfilling the needs of the entire family. Her husband needs to perform maintenance on his taxi because the current condition of his taxi is not good. It requires more maintenance charges on a daily basis. Due to insufficient financial means, her husband is unable to perform maintenance on his taxi. Therefore, Sajida has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

With the help of this loan, Sajida’s husband can afford the maintenance cost easily and provide better transportation services to earn profitable income. Sajida also plans to save some of her husband’s income to meet her family’s needs in the future.

Sajida is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to repair her husband's taxi.

loans.name: Mwape

texts.en:
Mwape is 30 years old. He is married and has two children, 1-year-old Chishimba and 3-year-old Misheck. Mwape works hard to provide for his family.

Mwape completed secondary school and college before accounting and budgeting. He has since started his own Zoona business. Mwape enjoys his business because it allows him to gain invaluable experience in customer service matters, and it gives the people in his community access to financial services without any barriers.

Mwape is requesting a loan in order to expand his business from one outlet to two and bring financial services to more communities. He described himself as a driven and hardworking man who dreams of achieving success in business in order to further support his family and his children’s education.

When Mwape receives this loan, he will be able to purchase two trading booths, one small and one big. The trading booths will be placed in two different spots; the big booth will go to Ndola town, where there is more traffic, and he will place the small one in Luanshya, which is a smaller town compared to Ndola. Mwape has done a lot of market research and is confident of the two locations where he wants to expand his business. Opening these two locations will enable Mwape to hire two new people to help him run the outlets.

This loan means a lot to Mwape. It will give him the chance to grow his business and improve his standard of living as well as provide employment to other people in his community. He thanks the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase two trading booths and serve people who need to access financial services in Luanshya and Ndola.

loans.name: Ethel

texts.en:
This is thirty-four-year-old Ethel. She is married and has two children. Ethel is requesting a loan from Kiva in order for her to set up her own mobile money transfer business at one of the busiest bus terminals in Lusaka, the capital city of Zambia.

Ethel's business will provide financial services such as sending and receiving of money and bill payments. She says the business will benefit her community, as they will be able to transact at their convenience and save on costs because they will not have to travel long distances to access financial services. She is very happy with the opportunity to start running her own business and access working capital finance through Kiva. She explains that accessing loans in Zambia is a major challenge because of high interest rates.

When Ethel receives this loan, she will be able to set up her business by purchasing a branded kiosk and having the funds needed for her to start serving people. She looks forward to starting to operate her business. This loan will change Ethel's life, as she will be able to earn extra income and provide for her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy a Zoona-branded kiosk and provide the funds needed for her to start operating her mobile money transfer business.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 52 years old. She is single and has seven children. She runs a business providing mobile money transfer services to people in her community and hopes to one day send two of her eldest children to study in university. Her children take turns throughout the week helping her with the business after school.

Margaret describes herself as very hardworking, honest, and dedicated. Her business environment is great, because of where she is located. Her location has many potential customers. Margaret wants to get a loan to increase her working capital, as this will enable her to serve more customers. She will also use the loan to purchase a small trading booth, as the one she is currently using is not hers. Owning her booth will help her save on operational costs.

Margaret hopes to open more mobile money outlets because she believes that her community benefits from her business by having an inexpensive way of moving their money in a safe environment. She is grateful for the opportunity to be connected to Kiva lenders, as the capital injected into her business will help her to earn more profits. The profits will be used to provide for her seven children.

loans.use: to buy a small Zoona-branded trading booth and have the electronic funds needed to serve customers who need to access mobile money services in her community.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 59 years old. She has three children and comes from a family of four. She is the bread-winner in the family, as she is the only one of four children who managed to complete high school and go to college. For the past four months, Susan has been running a mobile money business in Mkushi. She provides financial services to people in her community and is very passionate about customer service.

Susan is retired; when she is not at her money transfer booth, she can be found at her farm where she grows maize crops for sale. She started the business of mobile money when she saw the need for financial services in her town of Mkushi. Susan makes all her transactions on her mobile phone. Her business benefits her community because it provides an accessible and affordable financial services platform that allows her clients to send money around Zambia and top up airtime in an easy, quick and safe manner.

Susan has requested a loan through Zoona so that she can purchase the small trading booth that she currently uses to operate her business. This will reduce her operational costs. The loan will also help her to increase her capital. Her biggest dream is to grow her business so that she can leave a legacy for her children and family members.

loans.use: to buy a Zoona trading booth and provide the funds for her to increase her capital

loans.name: Owen

texts.en:
32-year-old Owen is married and has a son.  He lives in a remote area called Senanga in the western part of Zambia. He  makes a living by helping people who need to send and receive money from one place to the other. He is working towards expanding his business so that he can provide a better life for his wife and son.

Owen would like to thank his Kiva lenders for the help they gave him in raising his first two loans. He says the loans helped him open an outlet in Mulobezi, another remote area in the western province. Owen now has two outlets and has fully repaid his two loans.

Today, Owen is taking out another loan because he needs to open another Mobile money transfer outlet, he explains that because his outlets are in rural areas, his profit margins are very low, hence the need for him to open another outlet, so that he can have more volumes of transactions. He needs the loan in order to purchase a Zoona branded trading kiosk. The kiosk is where he will serve customers at his new location. This loan will also help Owen have the funds needed for him to serve people who need to access his services on a daily basis.

loans.use: To grow his business by purchasing a new trading kiosk and opening a new mobile money transfer outlet

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to supply more milk for more for more income gain, so as to educate her children

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John from Lusaka, Zambia, feels very blessed for the tremendous support from Kiva lenders who have helped him develop and run a mobile money transfer business to earn income for him and his family. He works very hard and can be found at his green trading booths every day from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. John is 37 years old; he is married and has three children.

John has been running his business for three years. He is a mobile money transfer agent; this means that for every transaction that John makes, he earns a profit. He currently operates three mobile money transfer outlets within Lusaka, and has employed three people to help him with the day-to-day running of the business. Through running this business, John has been able to take his children to school and pay for rent, as he lives in a rented house. The business has also helped him to furnish his house, and this makes him proud.

John would like to take this opportunity to let his lenders know that he has fully repaid his last two loans. He is now requesting another loan so that he can continue to grow his business by opening up another mobile money outlet. He will use the funds to buy a trading kiosk and serve people who need to access financial services in Chazanga compound, where he is going to set up the new kiosk. Once he sets up another kiosk, John will be able to employ one more person. He thanks the Kiva lenders for their help in providing for his family.

loans.use: to buy a trading kiosk and serve people who need to access financial services in Lusaka's Chazanga compound

loans.name: Giorgi

texts.en:
Giorgi is 24 years old. He lives in the Tsalenjikha district with his wife, parents, sister. The income of the family is only from agricultural activities. In particular, they have a plot of agricultural land, where they grow nut trees, which they sell locally. As the income is only seasonal and not enough for the family, Giorgi decided to start an additional business.

The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables him to get a loan for purchasing a cow. As the cow is purchased, the family will start producing dairy products and will be able to generate more income.

loans.use: to purchase a cow, to provide a new, non-seasonal, income for the welfare of his family

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is 33 years old. She is hardworking and determined. Faith is requesting a second Kiva loan to expand her business by opening three mobile money transfer outlets in different locations. She has found great locations and is sure that she will earn good profits once she starts operating.

Faith’s business involves the sending and receiving of money. Her business provides easy-to-access financial services to the community. She explains that a lot of people in Zambia are still unbanked and do not have access to proper financial services and that providing the service to her community makes her happy. 

When she gets the loan, Faith will be able to employ three young people to help her to serve her customers, which will scale her business even further. She will use the funds to purchase three quality trading kiosks to operate her business from. The funds will also add to her working capital for servicing customers at the new locations. 

Faith would like to take this opportunity to thank Kiva lenders for empowering her to start and to grow her business by having access to microloans.

loans.use: to buy three trading kiosks to expand her business by opening up more outlets.

loans.name: Sidra

texts.en:
Sidra is a simple house wife and lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been providing transport facilities by driving a taxi for twenty years. Her husband is responsible to fulfill the needs of entire family. Her husband needs to do maintenance of his taxi because the current condition of his taxi is not good and it requires more maintenance charges on a daily basis. 

Due to insufficient financial means her husband is unable to carry out the maintenance of his taxi. Therefore Sidra has applied for Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan.
With the help of this loan Sidra's husband can afford the maintenance cost easily. And provide the better transport facilities to earn the profitable income. Sidra  also plans to make savings with the profit amount of her husband's income to meet her family's needs in future.

Sidra is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to help repair her husband's taxi and make savings for the family needs

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a married woman with 4 children. She describes herself to be competent. She operates a posho mill where she grinds maize to produce flour. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her business is located in a market area and her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be low stock. 

She will use the Kes 60,000 loan to buy more stock of cereals. She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable income. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of cereals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farm input for higher production so as to earn more income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to distribute milk for more income using his motorcycle.

loans.name: Godwin

texts.en:
Godwin is a married man. He has 4 children. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a retail business where he sells sugar, bread, milk, flour and other items. He has been involved in this business for 20 years. His business is located in a busy area and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be low stock. 

He will use the Kes 35,000 loan to buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour, soap and other items. His business goal is to own a mini super market within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will have improved living standards. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of sugar, bread, flour, soap and other items

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana is 40 years old. She has had a hard life as she had to take care of her family. However, she manged to finish elementary school. Later she got married and they have one child. Her husband is an electrician. 

Diana has a space in her house where she sells soft drinks and pork meat to her customers. She has been doing this business for six years. Diana needs a loan to buy more merchandise (soft drinks and pork meat) to sell to her customers which increase daily due to the good treatment they get. 

Diana dreams of having a cafe in order to get ahead and to be able to have a better quality of living for her child. She also hopes that her child will become a professional and a good person.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise (soft drinks and pork meat) to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Jyotsna

texts.en:
Jyotsna is a 46-year-old active, hardworking woman who is married and has three sons.  She is from Alipurduar. Previously she worked as a nurse.  She left that job and now she wants to start a small sewing business.  Her sons are engaged with income-generating work. Her husband is an old man; he can no longer work to support his family. 

Jyotsna wants to start a home-based sewing business, a skill which she learned in her young age, to generate income for her family. She will stitch ladies' and kids' garments initially to grow her customer base.  There is a very good demand for expert seamstresses in her locality, so Jyotsna hopes the business will earn a lot of revenue for the family's livelihood. Her biggest challenge is capital.

In order to turn her dream into reality, Jyotsna has taken a loan from Kiva's partner BJS. She intends to use this loan to purchase a new sewing machine, fabrics, and some spools of thread. Jyotsna is very thankful to her lenders for the loan and hopes that this loan will further support her financially.

Her biggest dream is to expand her business and someday open a garment shop.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine to start a sewing business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To maximise her purchasing power on her trips to China.

loans.name: Marine

texts.en:
Marine is 46 years old and comes from the village of Bichnigaurebi. She lives with her husband, pensioner parents, and brother-in-law. The only income for their family is pensions; that is hardly enough to even cover basic needs. Marine and her husband had been working in a furniture factory in the capital but because of her husband's  ill-health, they were forced to leave the work and return to the village. 

Marine and her husband have no source of income nowadays and want to continue their past activity. Marine requested a loan for opening a small furniture factory to make a stable source of income. She received the credit in the framework of the joint initiative of Kiva and Credo - Startup Program that gives rural poor people the chance to start or re-start businesses.  

Marine and her husband will purchase all needed tools and equipment and will start furniture-making. They will get private orders and will continue doing their lovely job. They will be very thankful for the financial support, as their family's living conditions will significantly improve, thanks to Kiva lenders, and the family will have enough money to achieve financial stability.

loans.use: To start furniture-making and open a small factory

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a married woman. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells printing papers, glue, pens and other stationery. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in an area with lots of customers and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of stationery. Her business goal is to have a very big stationery shop that will enable her to distribute her products to big offices and schools within five years. She hopes that in the future, her children will have a good education. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of stationery

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy shirts, pants, socks, and underwear to sell.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: Nasreen is 38 years old. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a responsible mother of three children. Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. For the past many days, his rickshaw has not been working properly, causing him to be unable to generate any amount of income. Her husband wants to repair the rickshaw as soon as possible. However, due to the lack of money, her husband finds it difficult to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. Therefore, Nasreen has requested a loan from Kiva’s partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. This will help him to continue his business. Nasreen is so very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to help her husband to cover the cost of repairing his rickshaw.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen is a simple housewife and mother of six children. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been running a food stall; her husband sells different types of edible items, e.g., samosa, vegetable rolls, chicken tikka, Kabab paratha, etc. Her husband is solely responsible to feed the entire family and manage the household.

Parveen's husband needs to purchase different types of edible and other items for his business purposes so that he can increase the size of his business, improve his sales growth and earn maximum profit. But due to an unfavorable financial position, her husband is not in condition to purchase these items for his business purposes.

Therefore, Parveen has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan so that she can help her husband to purchase the above items for his business purposes.
 
She is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her husband's food stall business

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared is 36 years old, married to Agnes and supports two children. He is a dairy farmer and has been supplying milk to his customers for the last eight years.
 
He will use the loan to buy a dairy cow for milk production in hopes this will enable him to get more milk for selling and make him more income to support his family. He plans to use the anticipated profits to educate his children. 

His future hopes and dreams are to expand his dairy farming, supply more milk and be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow for milk production in hopes this will enable him to get more milk for selling and make him more income to support his family.

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Venus is 69 years old and an active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a mother of seven sons and three daughters; one of her sons has been doing a scrap recycling business.

Venus' son needs to buy scrap material in bulk to recycle it, but due to some financial constraints, her son is not in a suitable position to buy the scrap in bulk; therefore, Venus has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. This loan amount will enable her son to purchase the scrap material in bulk so that her son can easily adopt the recycling procedures and earn profitable income derived from his business.

Venus is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan for this financial assistance.

loans.use: to increase her son's recycled material business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to supply more milk for more income gain.

loans.name: Lisper

texts.en:
Lisper is 28 years old. She is married to Paul, and she supports two children. She has been selling chips in the market for the last three years, and the business earns 9,000 KES per month. 

Lisper has applied for her first loan of 25,000 KES from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase more potatoes and cooking oil for making chips to sell to clients, to meet both client and family needs.

Lisper plans to use the anticipated profits to repay the loan and to educate her children. Her hope is to be financially stable and to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more potatoes and cooking oil for making chips to sell to clients.

loans.name: Paata

texts.en:
Paata is 33 years old. He is married and lives with his wife and two infant sons in Gurjaani district, Kakheti region. Paata works physically to generate some income to feed his family. Sometimes he uses his car to serve locals as a taxi driver. 

He wants to start a trading business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables Paata to get a loan for purchasing calves. He will raise them and resell them at a higher price. This will give him a chance to generate more income and improve the living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to begin trading cattle in order to generate a stable icome

loans.name: María Delmy

texts.es:
María, de 42 años de edad, está soltera, trabaja haciendo los oficios domésticos de su casa, estudio hasta tercer grado, es madre soltera y tiene cinco hijos, tres viven con ella y estudian y los otros trabajan en la agricultura.

María, además de los oficios domésticos y la agricultura, también tiene crianza de cerdos, los cuales vende cuando tiene alguna necesidad para obtener ingresos. 

María, necesita el dinero para comprar abono, pesticidas, herbicidas y pagar la mano de obra para preparar la tierra y poder cultivarla. 

En un futuro María, sueña con ver a sus hijos convertidos en profesionales.
texts.en:
María, 42, is single and is a homemaker. She has a 3rd grade education. She is a single mother who has five children. Three of them live with her and go to school and the others work in agriculture.

In addition to being a homemaker and working in agriculture, María also raises pigs. She sells them when she needs to obtain income.
